study_duration: Patients were monitored for at least four weeks, but the duration of massage therapy was not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Integrated Rehabilitation Techniques of Traditional Chinese Medicine (IRT-TCM), which includes massage, as an alternative therapy for ischemic stroke patients compared to conventional rehabilitation techniques.
results_summary: IRT-TCM, combining acupuncture and massage, showed significantly better scores in lower limb function (FMA) and stroke severity (NIHSS) compared to conventional rehabilitation at 21 and 90 days. However, no significant difference was found in the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) between groups at day 90.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine patients with ischemic stroke (46 in the intervention group, 23 in the control group).
study_duration: 90 days (measurements taken at baseline, day 21, and day 90)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of foot massage versus quiet presence on physiological stress responses (blood pressure and heart rate) in individuals with moderate-to-severe dementia in long-term care settings.
results_summary: Foot massage led to a greater reduction in heart rate compared to quiet presence, though the difference was not statistically significant. Both groups experienced reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with a slightly greater reduction in systolic blood pressure for the foot massage group.
population_specificity: Individuals with moderate-to-severe dementia residing in long-term care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manual lymphatic drainage and bandaging (decongestive therapy) provided significant improvement in arm lymphedema compared to compression garments alone in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in percent reduction of excess arm volume between the experimental (decongestive therapy) and control (compression garments) groups, though absolute volume loss was slightly greater in the experimental group. Quality of life and arm function did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Women previously treated for breast cancer with lymphedema (≥10% volume difference between arms).
effective_dosage: Daily manual lymphatic drainage and bandaging followed by compression garments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a massage protocol in relieving pain in children hospitalized with cancer.
results_summary: The massage protocol was effective in reducing pain interference with walking and contributed to pain relief and improved activity levels. Each session significantly decreased pain intensity.
population_specificity: Children aged 10-18 years hospitalized in a pediatric cancer ward.
effective_dosage: Three sessions of 20-30 minutes on alternate days over one week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine educational accreditation standards for massage therapy and other CAM disciplines to identify competencies that facilitate interprofessional collaboration in healthcare.
results_summary: The study identified public health and other competencies in accreditation standards that may support interprofessional education and collaboration among healthcare practitioners, including massage therapists.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on educational standards, not a clinical population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify competencies for integrating complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) professions, including Massage, into conventional healthcare and foster collaboration between CAM and conventional healthcare providers.
results_summary: The study discussed the development of a competency document by ACCAHC, highlighting two unique domains (evidence-informed practice and institutional healthcare practices) not present in conventional healthcare's IPEC document, aiming to improve healthcare delivery and outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on healthcare professions and educators)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic relevance of neuroautonomic evaluation (including carotid sinus massage) in patients with unexplained falls versus those with unexplained syncope.
results_summary: Carotid Sinus Syndrome prevalence was similar in both groups (14.3% in falls vs. 10.5% in syncope). Neuroautonomic evaluation (tilt testing or carotid sinus massage) was positive in 61% of fall patients and 64% of syncope patients, showing no significant difference.
population_specificity: Older patients (mean age 75.3 years for falls, 63.2 years for syncope) with unexplained falls or syncope.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of various interventions, including ice massage, in treating medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS).
results_summary: Ice massage was found to be potentially effective in treating MTSS compared to control, though the evidence level was low (Level 3 to 4). No significant differences were found for other treatments like lower leg braces or iontophoresis.
population_specificity: Athletes and military personnel with MTSS.

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of conducting a randomized controlled trial of massage therapy for patients with a new spinal cord injury (SCI) during acute inpatient rehabilitation and assess its effects on pain and fatigue.
results_summary: Pain intensity was higher at baseline and reduced more in the light contact touch (LCT) group compared to the broad compression massage (BCM) group in the first period, but this difference was not observed in the second period. No significant differences were found in secondary measures except for depressive symptoms (PHQ-9).
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ undergoing acute rehabilitation following a spinal cord injury (SCI) and reporting any type of pain.
effective_dosage: Six 20-minute treatment sessions over 2 weeks, with a 1-week washout between treatment periods.
study_duration: 2 weeks per treatment period (total 5 weeks including washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a multimodal CAM program, including massage therapy, for reducing anxiety in individuals with GAD.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in anxiety using the GAD-7 and DASS-21 scales, with secondary improvements in pain and reduced use of anxiolytic medications. Massage was part of the multimodal intervention, but its individual effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: Military treatment facility volunteers with GAD (N = 37, 68% completion rate).
effective_dosage: Self- or partner-assisted massage therapy using scented oils (frequency not specified beyond being part of a 6-week program).

study_goal: To determine if sustained transabdominal uterine massage reduces blood loss after vaginal delivery when combined with oxytocin compared to oxytocin alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in blood loss between the group receiving oxytocin plus uterine massage and the group receiving oxytocin alone. Secondary outcomes also showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Women who delivered vaginally.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of sustained transabdominal uterine massage after delivery of the placenta.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short- and long-term benefits of massage therapy on stable preterm infants, focusing on outcomes such as pain response, neurodevelopment, weight gain, and breastfeeding duration.
results_summary: Massaged infants showed significantly lower pain scores (PIPP) after heel-stick procedures and at discharge, as well as higher cognitive scores at 12 months corrected age. No differences were observed in weight gain, length of hospital stay, breastfeeding duration, or motor scores between groups.
population_specificity: Stable preterm infants from tertiary-level NICUs in two university hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the benefits of Indian head massage (IHM) in enhancing patient experiences and promoting a therapeutic environment in a mental health ward for women.
results_summary: Feedback from patients and staff indicated positive individual experiences and that IHM enhanced the overall care experience. The outcomes suggest potential benefits of IHM in ward environments, prompting consideration of staff training in this complementary therapy.
population_specificity: Women in an acute inpatient mental health assessment and treatment ward.
effective_dosage: Six taster treatments (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify interventions, including massage, that support and improve the health of nurses.
results_summary: The study found that massage, among other holistic practices, was used as an intervention to improve nurses' health, though specific efficacy details were not provided. The abstract highlights a critical need for more research on such interventions.
population_specificity: Nurses working in clinical settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of classic massage versus massage based on the tensegrity principle for patients with chronic idiopathic shoulder pain.
results_summary: Massage based on the tensegrity principle showed statistically significant improvements in passive and active ranges of motion for flexion and abduction of the glenohumeral joint. Both massage groups demonstrated pain reduction, though the tensegrity group had superior motion-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with chronic idiopathic shoulder pain.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions over 2 weeks, each session lasting 20 minutes.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up measurements at 1 month post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reflexology was inferior to aromatherapy massage in addressing self-selected problems or concerns among cancer patients.
results_summary: Reflexology was found to be no less effective than aromatherapy massage for addressing first concerns, with no significant differences observed for second concerns, overall well-being, clinical benefit proportions, or relaxation scores between the two groups.
population_specificity: Adult outpatients recruited from a UK cancer center.
effective_dosage: Four sessions of either aromatherapy massage or reflexology.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by four sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence, patterns, and perceived benefits of complementary therapies, including massage, among hemifacial spasm patients and compare these findings across different movement disorders.
results_summary: Facial massage was used by 17.6% of hemifacial spasm patients, with some reporting perceived benefit, though specific efficacy details were not provided. Across movement disorders, massage trials ranged from 7-38%, with varying reported benefits.
population_specificity: Hemifacial spasm patients and broader movement disorder populations (Parkinson's disease, Tourette syndrome, dystonia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effects of continuous Japanese Anma massage therapy on alleviating physical and psychological symptoms in cancer survivors and to confirm the immediate effects of a single session.
results_summary: The study assessed the severity of physical subjective symptoms, psychological condition, and health-related quality of life in cancer survivors, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes included urine and saliva analyses.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (older than 20 years) with a history of gynecological cancers (uterine cervical, endometrial, ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal) and no recurrence for over 3 years post-treatment.
effective_dosage: 40-minute Anma massage sessions once weekly for 2 months (total of 8 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms of naturopathic reflex therapies like massage in influencing chronic pain, particularly at the peripheral nociceptor and spinal cord levels.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that naturopathic reflex therapies, including massage, may reduce chronic pain symptoms by affecting nociceptive pathways, but these hypotheses lack systematic testing. Quantitative sensory testing (QST) is proposed as a method to investigate these mechanisms further.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not mention a specific study population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neurobiological mechanisms of reflex therapies like massage in reducing chronic pain symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that reflex therapies, including massage, are effective in reducing chronic pain symptoms, likely through both brain mechanisms and peripheral nociceptor and spinal cord pathways. However, the neurobiological basis of these effects remains understudied.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term (48-month) effects of anthroposophic treatments, including rhythmical massage therapy, on symptoms and quality of life in patients with chronic conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in symptom severity and quality of life across all measured outcomes, with large effect sizes for most comparisons, including those involving rhythmical massage therapy. Improvements were sustained over the 48-month follow-up period.
population_specificity: 1,510 outpatients aged 1-75 years with chronic conditions (e.g., asthma, anxiety disorders, migraine, depression, ADHD, low back pain) in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Shiatsu massage on fibromyalgia symptoms, assess patient acceptability, and determine feasibility for a larger study.
results_summary: Shiatsu massage significantly improved pain intensity, pressure pain threshold, sleep quality, and symptom impact on health, with no adverse effects reported and high patient satisfaction. No clinically relevant effects were observed for anxiety.
population_specificity: Adult patients (33-62 years) with primary fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether aromatherapy (3% lavender oil spray) with and without hand massage could reduce disruptive behavior in people with dementia living in long-term care.
results_summary: The study found a downward trend in disruptive behaviors but none of the interventions (combination, aromatherapy alone, or placebo) significantly reduced disruptive behavior. Further large-scale studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: People with dementia and a history of disruptive behavior in long-term care facilities.
effective_dosage: Twice daily for six weeks (specific massage duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of physical therapy, including massage, on eating pathology and physiological/psychological parameters in patients with anorexia and bulimia nervosa.
results_summary: Massage significantly lowered scores of eating pathology and depressive symptoms in patients with anorexia and bulimia nervosa. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with anorexia and bulimia nervosa (age range: 16-36 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two traditional Ayurvedic massage treatments (navarakizhi and pinda sweda) for hemiplegia and demonstrate the feasibility of double-blind trials in Ayurvedic settings.
results_summary: Patients receiving navarakizhi showed better range of movement compared to those receiving pinda sweda. The study also confirmed that double-blind randomized trials are possible in Ayurvedic procedure-based therapies.
population_specificity: 18 patients with hemiplegia (disease duration 6 months to 2 years).
effective_dosage: 7 days of massage treatment (navarakizhi or pinda sweda) plus 14 days of oral Ayurvedic medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage therapy, exercise therapy, and their combination on pain, fatigue, spasticity, balance, gait, and quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Massage therapy showed significantly greater improvements in pain reduction, dynamic balance, and walking speed compared to exercise therapy. The combination of massage and exercise therapy resulted in larger pain reduction than exercise therapy alone.
population_specificity: 48 patients with multiple sclerosis.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions over five weeks (standard Swedish massage for the massage group, combined strength, stretch, endurance, and balance exercises for the exercise group).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of uterine massage after birth and before or after delivery of the placenta to reduce postpartum blood loss and associated morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The review found no statistically significant difference in blood loss ≥500 mL with uterine massage, though mean blood loss was significantly reduced at 30 and 60 minutes in one trial. Uterine massage did not add benefit over oxytocin alone in another trial.
population_specificity: Postpartum women in under-resourced settings (Egypt and South Africa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence and factors associated with CAM use, including massage, among patients with Parkinson's disease worldwide.
results_summary: Massage was identified as one of the frequently utilized CAM therapies for improving motor symptoms in PD patients, though the study did not specifically evaluate its efficacy or safety. CAM use was correlated with various sociodemographic and disease-specific factors.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the need for well-designed clinical trials to evaluate the efficacy and safety of complementary and integrative therapies, including massage, for children with mental health conditions.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about massage's effects, only noting that existing literature on complementary approaches is limited and more rigorous studies are needed.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with psychiatric conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the curative effect and safety of Duhuojisheng Tang, including its combination with massage, for treating prolapse of the lumbar intervertebral disc.
results_summary: The study found that Duhuojisheng Tang, both alone and combined with other therapies like massage, effectively improved pain and clinical symptoms in patients with lumbar disc prolapse, though the methodological quality of included trials was low.
population_specificity: 3915 patients with prolapse of the lumbar intervertebral disc.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) could reduce edema and pain and improve knee range of motion in the early postoperative period after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: MLD significantly improved active knee flexion compared to the control group at day 4 and 6 weeks post-surgery, but no significant effects were observed for other outcomes like pain or limb girth.
population_specificity: Patients (N=43; 53 knees) scheduled for TKA.
effective_dosage: MLD administered on days 2, 3, and 4 postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of massage therapy, including trigger-point therapy, as a treatment for carpal tunnel syndrome.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in symptom severity and functional status from two weeks onward, with results showing strong statistical significance (p < 0.001). The combination of massage and trigger-point therapy was deemed a viable treatment option for carpal tunnel syndrome.
population_specificity: 21 participants with carpal tunnel syndrome.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of massage, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of partner-delivered home-based cupping massage versus progressive muscle relaxation in reducing chronic non-specific neck pain.
results_summary: Both cupping massage and progressive muscle relaxation significantly reduced neck pain compared to baseline, with no significant differences between the two treatments. Cupping massage showed additional benefits in improving well-being and decreasing pressure pain sensitivity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic non-specific neck pain (mean age 54.1±12.7 years; 73.8% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of myofascial release (MFR) and Swedish massage on symptom burden and localized pain in women with fibromyalgia (FM).
results_summary: The MFR group showed a positive trend in overall symptom improvement compared to Swedish massage, with consistent pain reductions in the neck and upper back regions, though between-group differences in the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire Revised (FIQ-R) were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Women with fibromyalgia (FM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence for the effectiveness of exercise therapy and mobilisation techniques, including massage, for treating medial and lateral epicondylitis.
results_summary: Moderate evidence was found for the short-term effectiveness of stretching plus strengthening exercises compared to ultrasound plus friction massage. Additionally, moderate evidence supported the short-term and mid-term effectiveness of spinal manipulation as an add-on therapy to stretching and mobilisation for lateral epicondylitis. Other interventions showed limited or conflicting evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with lateral epicondylitis (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the indication and timing of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) use following severe hypothermic cardiac arrest, not Massage.
results_summary: The study found CPB rewarming superior to conventional methods in survival and neurological outcomes, with ECMO showing better survival rates than CPB in one comparison.
population_specificity: Patients with severe hypothermic cardiac arrest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of conservative interventions, including massage, for treating exercise-related groin pain in athletes.
results_summary: One study found no significant difference between multimodal therapy (including massage) and exercise therapy for successful treatment or return to sports, though multimodal therapy resulted in a slightly earlier return. Another study found exercise therapy superior to conventional physiotherapy (including massage) in short-term outcomes.
population_specificity: Male athletes aged 18-50 with adductor-related groin pain lasting at least two months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes, particularly early mortality, of emergency cardiac surgeries following life-threatening complications from cardiac catheterization procedures.
results_summary: The study found a 1% 30-day mortality rate in patients requiring emergency surgery after cardiac catheterization complications, comparable to general open cardiac surgery outcomes. Postoperative myocardial infarction and prolonged ventilator use were higher in the emergency group, but other complications were similar.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent emergency cardiac surgery after complications from diagnostic or therapeutic cardiac catheterization (n=100).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of massage therapy as a complementary treatment for neck pain.
results_summary: The abstract indicates low-quality evidence supporting the beneficial effects of massage therapy for neck pain, with complications generally being benign and self-limited, though rare catastrophic consequences have been documented.
population_specificity: Patients with neck pain seeking complementary and alternative medicine (CAM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence base for complementary therapies, including massage, in improving symptoms and quality of life for lung cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage, among other complementary therapies, can be helpful in improving overall care for lung cancer patients, addressing symptoms like anxiety, mood disturbance, pain, and treatment-related side effects. The evidence supports integrating massage with standard cancer therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with lung cancer

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a complex Ayurvedic treatment, including massage, against conventional methods for managing symptoms of knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study evaluated changes in WOMAC scores and other secondary outcomes but did not provide specific results for massage alone; the abstract indicates the trial design balanced rigor and pragmatism.
population_specificity: 150 patients aged 40-70 with knee osteoarthritis, diagnosed per American College of Rheumatology criteria and baseline pain ≥40 mm on a VAS.
effective_dosage: 15 treatment sessions over 12 weeks (specific massage dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lumbar massage during the active phase of labour could reduce pain severity compared to standard care.
results_summary: Massage significantly reduced pain severity (mean difference of 20mm on a visual analogue scale) but did not affect other pain-related measures or obstetric outcomes except for a slightly longer labour duration in the massage group. Both groups reported high satisfaction with the physiotherapist's care.
population_specificity: 46 pregnant women at ≥37 weeks gestation with spontaneous labour onset, 4-5cm cervical dilation, intact membranes, and no medication use after hospital admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of DNA methylation patterns in biological specimens, including post-prostatic massage urine, for early detection and prognosis of genitourinary neoplasms.
results_summary: The study identified specific aberrant DNA methylation patterns in tumor samples compared to healthy tissues, suggesting potential utility for early diagnosis and prognosis evaluation of genitourinary cancers. However, further validation and multicenter studies are needed to confirm accuracy and reproducibility.
population_specificity: Patients with urological neoplasms (prostate, bladder, renal, and testicular cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aromatherapy massage on psychological symptoms during menopause compared to massage therapy alone and no treatment.
results_summary: Both aromatherapy massage and massage therapy significantly reduced psychological symptoms in menopausal women, with aromatherapy massage showing a greater reduction in symptoms compared to massage therapy alone. The control group showed no significant change in psychological symptoms.
population_specificity: 90 women experiencing menopausal symptoms (87 evaluated).
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, twice a week, for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of tactile massage (TM) on metabolic biomarkers in patients with type 2 diabetes, comparing it to relaxation exercises.
results_summary: TM showed significant reductions in waist circumference for women and improvements in adiponectin levels and adiponectin-related ratios, but no significant effects on HbA1c. The clinical relevance of these metabolic marker changes needs further evaluation.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes in primary care.
effective_dosage: 10 weeks of TM once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage, among other CAM interventions, in reducing cancer-related fatigue.
results_summary: The review found limited evidence suggesting massage may help reduce cancer-related fatigue, but most studies were methodologically weak and at high risk of bias, making conclusions uncertain.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing fatigue during or after cancer treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether infant massage is effective in promoting infant physical and mental health in low-risk, population samples.
results_summary: The study found some significant benefits of infant massage for physical outcomes like weight, length, and sleep duration, but many results were not maintained after sensitivity analyses. Mental health outcomes showed limited significant effects, and overall evidence was deemed of poor quality.
population_specificity: Healthy parent-infant dyads with infants under six months old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage and matrix rhythm therapy on peripheral blood circulation in young women.
results_summary: Both massage and matrix rhythm therapy increased blood velocity, artery diameter, and blood flow, but matrix rhythm therapy resulted in more prominent increases in blood flow compared to massage.
population_specificity: Fifteen healthy women aged 19-23 years.
study_duration: Single 30-minute session for each intervention, with at least 1 week between sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of passive rest, sports massage, and sports massage with ozonised oil on performance and psycho-physiological indices in competitive amateur cyclists after fatiguing exercise.
results_summary: Sports massage with ozonised oil (SMOZO) resulted in higher peak power output, lower perceived fatigue, and greater blood lactate clearance compared to sports massage alone or passive rest. No significant differences in heart rate patterns were observed across the three conditions.
population_specificity: Fifteen male competitive amateur cyclists (age 27 ± 3.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of massage as a mechanostimulatory modality to exert anti-inflammatory and antifibrotic effects in muscular dystrophies like Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage, among other modalities, may help mitigate fibrosis and inflammation in DMD by activating protective mechanisms and hindering tissue degradation, though specific results for massage alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with muscular dystrophies, particularly Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current research status of Mind-Body Therapies (including massage) in pediatric oncology and discuss their efficacy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that massage, as part of MBTs, is of low risk and accessible for patients and their families during cancer therapy, with positive results including increased self-confidence and a more optimistic outlook.
population_specificity: Pediatric oncology patients and their families.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether myofascial rollers (a form of self-massage) could enhance athletic performance when used before athletic tests.
results_summary: Foam rolling did not improve performance in any of the athletic tests but reduced postexercise fatigue compared to planking. No significant differences were found between foam rolling and planking for performance metrics, though gender differences were noted in all tests.
population_specificity: 26 healthy college-aged individuals (13 men and 13 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize key clinical and research issues related to tendinopathy, including insights relevant to massage therapy, as discussed during the second International Scientific Tendinopathy Symposium.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about massage's effects, as it serves as an overview and conceptual framework rather than a detailed study.
population_specificity: Sportspeople or workers with tendinopathy, and health professionals involved in their care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Thai traditional massage on bone metabolism in postmenopausal women by measuring changes in biochemical markers of bone turnover.
results_summary: Thai traditional massage significantly increased serum P1NP, a marker of bone formation, particularly in older postmenopausal women with smaller body builds, while no significant changes were observed in osteocalcin or CTX. No significant changes in bone turnover markers were found during the control period.
population_specificity: 48 postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate pressure versus light pressure massage therapy on pain, grip strength, and range of motion in adults with rheumatoid arthritis in the upper limbs.
results_summary: The moderate pressure massage group showed reduced pain, improved grip strength, and greater range of motion in wrist and upper joints compared to the light pressure group after the first and last sessions, with sustained benefits after one month.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis in the upper limbs.
effective_dosage: Therapist-administered massage once a week and self-massage once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soft tissue massage affects the efficacy of mental and incisive nerve block anesthesia.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in anesthetic success or episodes of negative response between active (soft tissue massage) and control (premolar crown massage) treatments. Soft tissue massage did not influence the speed of anesthetic onset or discomfort levels.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight volunteers receiving mandibular nerve blocks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of massage versus active exercise on relieving delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in the upper trapezius muscle.
results_summary: Both massage and active exercise significantly reduced perceived soreness and increased pressure pain threshold (PPT), with the greatest effects occurring immediately after treatment for soreness and peaking at 20 minutes for PPT. Active exercise with elastic resistance provided similar acute relief as massage, though the effects diminished within an hour.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy female volunteers (mean age 32 years).
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of massage or 10 minutes of active exercise (shoulder shrugs 10 × 10 reps with increasing elastic resistance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the application of Chinese medicine modalities, including massage therapy (tuina), in physical rehabilitation scenarios, focusing on disabilities related to nervous, musculoskeletal, or cardiovascular systems.
results_summary: The study discussed both positive and negative results of Chinese medicine interventions, including massage, for rehabilitation, emphasizing the importance of personalized approaches and reproducible methods. Chinese medicine resources, including massage, were recognized as promising for therapeutic rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals with disabilities due to illnesses of the nervous, musculoskeletal, or cardiovascular systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of pseudocyst of the auricle and evaluate the role of chronic massage in managing its size.
results_summary: Chronic massage slightly decreased the size of the pseudocyst, but the condition persisted for many years. The study primarily focused on the etiology and treatment options rather than the efficacy of massage.
population_specificity: A 63-year-old man with a rugby-associated pseudocyst of the auricle.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the role of diagnostic tests, including carotid sinus massage, in evaluating patients with suspected syncope.
results_summary: The abstract mentions carotid sinus massage as one of the additional diagnostic tests used when initial evaluation is inconclusive, but it does not provide specific results regarding its efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected syncope.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of soft tissue massage, among other physiotherapy treatments, for chronic low back pain (CLBP) and its potential combination with lumbar facet joint injections.
results_summary: Soft tissue massage showed a positive short-term effect on CLBP, with possible longer-term benefits, though the evidence for lumbar spinal mobilizations was insufficient to draw conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of pacing therapy in vasovagal syncope (VVS) and carotid sinus syndrome (CSS), particularly focusing on the efficacy and appropriateness of carotid sinus massage as a diagnostic tool and the implications for treatment.
results_summary: The study found that pacing therapy should be considered for older patients with frequent VVS symptoms and documented asystole, as well as those with unexplained syncope showing a cardio-inhibitory or mixed response to carotid sinus massage (asystole >3 s). However, the evidence base for these recommendations is largely consensus-driven rather than derived from robust randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Older patients with frequent vasovagal syncope symptoms, unexplained syncope with cardio-inhibitory or mixed response to carotid sinus massage, and patients with unexplained falls or drop attacks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aerobic walking versus massage on functional status and health-related quality of life in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in the Physical Health Component of the SF-36 for the massage group, and the walking group showed significantly greater improvement in endurance (6-minute walk test). Massage was less effective than walking for improving physical health and endurance in stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors
effective_dosage: Not specified (massage was administered to the affected side)

study_goal: The researchers reviewed studies and case series on radiofrequency devices, including combination therapies that apply massage, to assess their use in aesthetic medicine.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that radiofrequency technology is used in combination with massage, but no specific results regarding massage's effects are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (general aesthetic medicine applications).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of an expedited noninvasive device treatment for cellulite and body measures.
results_summary: At 2 months, 93% of subjects showed improvements in at least one Cellulite Severity Scale category, and 60% improved in both the number and depth of depressions. Most patients (93%) reported satisfaction and willingness to repeat the treatment.
population_specificity: Fifteen female subjects aged 20 to 42 years.
effective_dosage: Three 30-minute treatment sessions per area over three consecutive days.
study_duration: Three days of treatment with follow-ups at 7, 30, and 60 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aromatherapy massage could reduce physical pain in patients undergoing postoperative face-down posturing (FDP) after vitrectomy.
results_summary: Both aromatherapy massage and plain oil massage provided short-term pain relief compared to usual care, with aromatherapy showing slightly better long-term effects by the third postoperative day. No significant differences were found between the aromatherapy and plain oil massage groups in most comparisons.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing postoperative face-down posturing (FDP) after vitrectomy (n=63).
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of massage per session (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Short-term (pre- to post-intervention) and long-term (first to third postoperative day) assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and side effects of ultrasound therapy combined with ice massage for treating patellofemoral knee pain syndrome.
results_summary: Ultrasound combined with ice massage showed a 15% improvement in pain relief compared to ice massage alone, but this difference did not meet clinically important standards. No significant differences were found in quadriceps and hamstring strengthening between the groups.
population_specificity: 53 participants with patellofemoral pain syndrome.
